FACEBOOK WILL END ON MARCH 15th!

FACEBOOK WILL END ON MARCH 15th!

Posted on Saturday, January 8th, 2011
By J.B. Smitts

Comments (20305)
Buzz up!
Print This
ShareThis

PALO ALTO, CA –Mark Zuckerberg announced that Facebook will be shut down in March. Managing the site has become too stressful.

“Facebook has gotten out of control,” said Zuckerberg in a press conference outside his Palo Alto office, “and the stress of managing this company has ruined my life. I need to put an end to all the madness.”

Zuckerberg went on to explain that starting March 15th, users will no longer be able to access their Facebook accounts.

“After March 15th the whole website shuts down,” said Avrat Humarthi, Vice President of Technical Affairs at Facebook. “So if you ever want to see your pictures again, I recommend you take them off the internet. You won’t be able to get them back once Facebook goes out of business.”

Zuckerberg said that the decision to shut down Facebook was difficult, but that he does not think people will be upset.

“I personally don’t think it’s a big deal,” he said in a private phone interview. “And to be honest, I think it’s for the better. Without Facebook, people will have to go outside and make real friends. That’s always a good thing.”

Some Facebook users were furious upon hearing the shocking news.

“What am I going to do without Facebook?” said Denise Bradshaw, a high school student from Indiana. “My life revolves around it. I’m on Facebook at least 10 hours a day. Now what am I going to do with all that free time?”

However, parents across the country have been experiencing a long anticipated sense of relief.

“I’m glad the Facebook nightmare is over,” said Jon Guttari, a single parent from Detroit. “Now my teenager’s face won’t be glued to a computer screen all day. Maybe I can even have a conversation with her.”

Those in the financial circuit are criticizing Zuckerberg for walking away from a multibillion dollar franchise. Facebook is currently ranked as one of the wealthiest businesses in the world, with economists estimating its value at around 7.9 billion.

But Zuckerberg remains unruffled by these accusations. He says he will stand by his decision to give Facebook the axe.

“I don’t care about the money,” said Zuckerberg. “I just want my old life back.”

The Facebook Corporation suggests that users remove all of their personal information from the website before March 15th. After that date, all photos, notes, links, and videos will be permanently erased.

  • Share this:

        I strongly disagree with the disabling of facebook. My brother was deployed overseas and although we email each other, FB is one of the only ways for him to stay connected with our family. Perhaps if the business is becoming too much for Mark Z, he should sell it instead of ending it for everyone because I know a lot of other families who benefit from it in the same way. As well as staying connected with my brother, its an EXCELLENT way of networking! Two recommendation letters have come my way by conversing with associates and various people through facebook.

      916. Pravab says:
        January 8th, 2011 at 8:06 pm

        All of the social networking sites popularity gets down after some years. Whether it is something new popping out or people getting board of the same old same old thing. People always wants to experience something new, something so they can live up with. But in the case of facebook, its different. It's gaining popularity every single day. There are various reason for it and people are sticking unto it. Although its coming to an end. it would be great if facebook gives the users the ability to play around with the page so that they have its own look before going to the grave.

        I personally wasn't much of facebook users but it has helped me met some old friends, see the old pictures which otherwise was locked up in a box in the closed, look at the updates of friends who otherwise wouldn't blog or email you about it (not because you are not important, but because they just don't fell like updating people through those medium) and so on.

        Mark Zuckerberg has played a big role bringing people together but at the end its his decision to shut it down for good. I absolutely agree with him looking at some of my friends life and comments in the article above. But for some people it would be devastating. Theres always a new thing to hold on to, but facebook would be always remembered.

        The article also mentions that 'all photos, notes, links, and videos will be permanently erased.'. I hope they delete the database entirely so that nothing is there, not even a 'bit' of any data.

        I also hope that Mark would go for something new this time. May be he would join F/LOSS and contribute to the community or may be he would join some proprietary company; but the thing is to look out for what this capable man has to offer in the near future.

        (You can post your reply in my blog article and the link is given below) http://pravab.blogspot.com/2011/01/facebook-endin…

      1594. This site is BS says:
        January 8th, 2011 at 9:39 pm

        Absolute rubbish. Facebook is a multi-billion dollar corporation with one of the world's largest advertising networks, if it became "too stressful", you wouldn't close the entire company (and dismiss all of the Facebook staff), you would sell the company and step down as managing director. Stopping the service completely is just not going to happen.

        This is just an attempt to make a viral article and get people talking about it, it will never happen, because Facebook is more than a social networking tool, it is a platform for other businesses and advertisement opportunities, a lot of the site other organisations rely on.

        This site should be shut down.

At least it is a rather harmless rumor and really just a bit of fun. Much better than the ones that were circulating the net at the start of the year, claiming some well known celebrities had died.____So Facebook fans across the planet, all 500 million plus of them, need not worry. No need to go out and start closing down your account and start looking for a facebook alternative, to fill in a vacant space in your life. Facebook is not coming to an end and is likely to be around for a very long time yet.____
